comments.commentBody: I recommend my mother's style of instruction: She let me knead dough, shape cookies, make pie crust, etc from the time I was three.  No boring tasks and no nagging about clean-up in the introductory lessons.  Her line was "Since you cooked, I'll help clean up."  That attitude, along with lots of praise and encouragement, formed her children into good, fearless and sometimes, _very_ competitive cooks.

My sons are showing increasing interest in helping me around the kitchen,  my four year old made fried rice the other day (with help of course) and my two year old is slowly mastering the art of cracking an egg.  I'm thrilled at their interest and hope to teach them all I know about cooking.

Sometimes I do like to be in the kitchen myself and enjoy it as time to myself. Personally, I need to concentrate at the task or it turns out miserably. Of course, sometimes my kids do help and enjoy it. The thing is they like to have total control over what they are doing and don't really want to follow directions. Last week I let my daughter and her friend form their own pan of cookies in any way they wanted. It was torture for me, but I kept my mouth shut and was really surprised by the varied results, all good: small balls, flattened pancakes, the giant cookie. It was fun and giving them the freedom to do it their way was what they loved, though challenging for me not to provide direction. I learned a great lesson that day about letting go of some control so that my kids can grow.

Sure it is great to involve the kids in cooking. But it is even more important to cook every day as a matter of course. My son could barely cook an egg when he left for college. But he was used to home cooking and that's what inspired him to start cooking himself.
Loved your article! And most importantly, cooking keeps kids and parents close; preparing family meals is a fundamental family function that builds lifetime memories to warm the heart!

I just returned from visiting my 3 year old grandson and 22 month old granddaughter with whom I spent much time in the kitchen. Instead of dashing out for greasy food we made meatballs and sauce, lemon ice box pie, red beans and rice. What fun it was for him to point out the "baby leaves" in the beans and carry the salad to the table and say " I made it ". These were memorable moments not spent in a drive through .

Maybe I wasn't clear: if the point of teaching kids to cook is mainly so that they can relieve their parent(s)/caregiver(s) of the task of making dinner--that's not a good enough reason. That makes the lesson benefit the parents more than the kids. That's why I said the kids need to show interest. If they are made to cook only because it's a chore that parents don't want to do, the message is clear: cooking is not fun, but something to be avoided. And we all know what fun planning and cooking are! (At  least for the first 40 years or so. After that, I've found it can get a bit tedious.)
Sorry, but these are all a little rich for everyday, tho many are delicious and are a match for the Reds even Ch Pape Clement.  I suggest Entre Deux Mers as an Everyman choice.
I have found that some of these more complex aged whites actually benefit from a wine finer or similar aeration device (usually reserved for reds).

When I look at our tasting notes it is clear we are no longer as diligent as we used to be. Or perhaps these white Bordeaux wines just left us slightly perplexed. Most of our comments are hedged: slightly this, mildly that, a touch of honey, dryish. We had Larrivet Haut-Brion Blanc 2010 (85% Sauvignon Blanc) and a local wine, Savage White 2014 (73% SB), with a fruit and feta salad with sweet chilli dressing, and with the main course of chicken with a light paprika sauce, L’Esprit de Chevalier Blanc 2012 and Vergelegen GVB White 2011, both of which have roughly equal amounts of SB and Sémillon. The difference between the French and local wines was much less pronounced than we have experienced with, for example, Sancerre and German Riesling. Probably the most successful wine of the evening was the Carbonnieux 2007; this may to a large extent have been the result of the excellent cheeses we had with it, Sainte Maure de Touraine (goat), Le Cousin (hard) and Baraka (cream enriched). We have not been converted to Bordeaux Blanc enthusiasts, but we are nonetheless happy to have been introduced to it.

Tuvw Xyz
I wish I knew you so I could to Thanksgiving I will bottles of wine

i read this article this past shabbous. nothing beats my bobbie's recipes which were all in her head and i was too young to write them down. unfortunately, my mother never made the recipes because my bobbbie brought over the finished product every thursday for shabbous. i wonder if the cookbook you mention in your article is still available -- i'm sure that i could find some if those recipes that went 6 feet under with my bobbie! i eagerly await your response.

wishing you a g'mar chatimah tovah...

I think what makes Jewish apple cake "Jewish" is that there's no dairy in the recipe - no butter or milk. So it can be served at a meat meal. Other cuisines might have similar recipes but they don't care if their desserts include butter.

Saw that the CAMPGROUND was right below SWAMPGAS; sure hope the PUPtent was really HIGH.
Also noted that Al HIRT (from last week) was hiding in PGT-HIRT-EEN. He can STEP right up to any of the VENUES or ARENAS.

IN SUM, despite the several abbreviations, this was a PRIMO puzzle.
Great. Simple!
This story reminds us of the talent that is often hidden and  that  emerges from years of adversity! I can't wait to purchase Ms Charles' cook book!

"Pistou is pasta"

Not. Pistou is what people in Provence call a basil plant.

comments.userLocation: Alphabet City - East Village - Manhattan - New York
comments.commentBody: I live a block away. Tried it. If there is such a thing as overhyped mediocrity in NYC restaurants today, it's personified by Babu Ji. The food is no different than anything you can get in Little India - for 75% less. And it's not the money, but the principle. It's just not that good, and after two small appetizers and a smaller "entre" the $102 bill felt like P. T. Barnum was back from the dead. "One born every minute!" I can hear him saying.

As a former New Yorker (now living in Scottsdale AZ) I salute chef Jonathan of Fung Tu for continuing to supply his customers with almost all of their choices in such frustrating circumstances. He should be applauded (and patronized) for his hard work and ingenuity!!!
Second person was fine with me.  Actually I found it a fresh take on the standard review format.  Like food...be creative!
Oh how I miss the Berly Brothers I've cream! And Basettes malts. If you ever make it to Philly, visit burn Franklin fountain in old city and Basettes in reading terminal, you won't be sorry!!!!

I can't see the image you posted but as long as the fire starter has no petrol/petroleum products added you should be fine. Before chimney starters were readily available here people used to make their own by placing holes in the bottom of a coffee can and inserting a bit of grill grate.  You can find several different ways to manufacture  a chimney starter by doing a web search under the following term:"homemade charcoal chimney starter".
I knew about Shemitah but not the association with economic disasters. I really don't need another hit to the NESTEGG.

RiA,

The Shemitah association with economic disasters is linked to the non-observance of the Shemitah. The last one, Sept. 29, 2008 was a 777-point, 7% loss on the DJIA. The one before that was the post-911 drop on Sept. 17, 2001. Go back two more Shemitahs and you have the 1987 crash. A week from now you'll know if your NESTEGG has weathered a possible storm. 1994 was not a severe crash, but bonds were affected.

As I recall, the end-of-the-world predictions have to do not only with Shemitah but also with Blood Moons and came from Pat Robertson or someone like that. I didn't really delve into it too much and don't want to go back and look (once was enough). Also relying on memory, there is some disagreement about the exact date, but definitely this month. I think we're supposed to get hit by an asteroid. Perhaps the one that missed us in 1982.

I'm with you, RiA. Having my retirement money basically cut in half in 2008 (when I was 66, but who's counting), I'm not anxious to lose more of my NEST EGG.

Shana Tova next week to all who observe. And those who don't.

Deadline,

Caught this one too late to reply on the Monday blog:

>>I guess you mean the economic-disaster predictions

Those are the only ones I know about and only by inference. Rabbi Jonathan Cahn who has written at least two best-sellers on the Shemitah, refuses to make any predictions. He can't because no one knows exactly what will happen. All I can say is that Elul 29 is next Sunday and stock markets don't crash on weekends unless it starts in China and works its way around the world. There is also a possibility of a monetary crisis and those do usually fall on weekends.

Next year is a Jubilee year by some reckonings. In the past that has always been good for the state of Israel. Shana Tova.
